Of course they ruled that a government action violated the state constition, but we cannot infer from this that they have done "exactly what they're paid for (I understand this to mean that they have acted legitimately)." If the proper way to measure legitimacy was to simply see if the court overturned a statute on the grounds that it violated the constitution, then we would have to say all kinds of disastrous things. We would be forced to say that the Taney court was only doing what it was paid for when it determined the Missouri Compromise to be unconstitutional. We would have to say that when Lochner Court held a New York maximum working hour law to be unconstitutional, it was only doing what it was paid for. These two cases are widely accepted as incorrect by legal scholars and jurists, even though the court purported to overturn the respective legislation because it was unconstitutional.
